awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Machine Learning and Data Assimilation for Discovery of Generalized Fokker-Planck Equation for Radiation Belt Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports a two-year investigation into a better understanding and prediction of the extreme dynamic regions of space known as the Van Allen radiation belts. The near-Earth radiation environment is filled with high-energy particles trapped by the Earth's magnetic field.  The particle intensity and distribution change as part of a much larger space weather system driven by the Sun.  The radiation belts can be hazardous for satellites and astronauts in space.  Therefore, it is crucial to be able to predict these energetic particles better for our space exploration.  

The new investigation is expected to lead to a more accurate understanding of the radiation belts using a novel combination of data assimilation and machine learning methods to discover generalized Fokker-Planck equations for radiation belt modeling. The Principal Investigator (PI) will use University of California-Los Angeles (UCLA)'s Versatile Electron Radiation Belt (VERB) model and data assimilation to learn and incorporate additional dynamical terms that would describe nonlinear wave-particle kinetic effects.  The project will promote and pave the way for novel use of machine learning and data assimilation tools to discover missing physics in high-dimensional and complex space physics models. The initial implementation and vetting of combined data assimilation and machine learning algorithms in the radiation belt diffusion model will not only lead to significant advances in space weather modeling capabilities. Still, they will also have substantial broader impacts on space plasma physics and other disciplines. The project will thus have the potential to drastically change our understanding of radiation belt modeling, and advanced tools can find broader use for Earth's climate studies and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview
The high-risk/high-payoff project aimed to understand and model the nonlinear wave-particle interactions (NL-WPI) affecting the dynamics of the Earth's radiation belts. By integrating NL-WPI effects through the rescaling of quasi-linear (QL) diffusion coefficients, the project aimed to enhance the existing Fokker-Planck (FP) diffusion equations within the UCLA Versatile Electron Radiation Belt (VERB) code. Additionally, we explored the reconstruction of radiation belts using data assimilation (DA) combined with machine learning (ML) techniques.

We selected the geomagnetic storm of October 9, 2012, as a case study for incorporating NL-WPI effects into the VERB code. Traditionally, this storm was modeled using QL diffusion rates in 2D FP simulations. However, these models failed to capture the rapid acceleration observed within two hours during the storm. By rescaling QL diffusion rates using theory-informed NL-WPI, our research significantly improved the accuracy of observed electron flux increases in diffusion simulations.

In addition to rescaling QL diffusion rates, we employed machine learning, uncertainty quantification, and physics-perturbed ensembles of VERB simulations, using Van Allen Probes observations to identify the optimal rescaling of QL diffusion rates. Our simulations accounted for rapid density depletion and were confined within the observed L* range.

We also reconstructed radiation belt electron fluxes using DA with low-Earth-orbiting POES measurements mapped to near-equatorial regions. Different machine learning approaches were explored, which helped to improve the accuracy of the VERB model when integrated with data assimilation.

Key Findings
1. Theory-Informed Rescaling of Quasi-Linear Diffusion Rates: Our study demonstrated that rescaling quasi-linear diffusion rates based on NL-WPI theory significantly improved the accuracy of observed electron flux increases in diffusion simulations during the geomagnetic storm of October 9, 2012.

2. Optimization of Rescaling Factor: Using machine learning, uncertainty quantification, and physics-perturbed ensembles of VERB simulations, we identified the optimal rescaling factor for quasi-linear diffusion rates.

3. ML and DA-Based Reconstruction of Radiation Belts: The integration of machine learning and data assimilation methods enhanced the reconstruction of radiation belt electron fluxes, showing that data assimilation can improve the accuracy even when an optimized machine learning model is not feasible.

Conclusions

Our study demonstrated that accurately modeling rapid electron flux enhancements during strong geomagnetic storms requires theory-informed NL-WPI rescaling of QL diffusion rates. The attached figure shows the dynamics of normalized omnidirectional electron fluxes, illustrating that VERB simulations with NL-WPI rescaled diffusion rates provide much better agreement with observed flux increases compared to QL diffusion rates. Additionally, data assimilation with low-Earth-orbiting POES measurements significantly improved the accuracy of the VERB model by correcting mapping errors.

The ML and DA-based reconstruction methodology enables continuous monitoring of the radiation belt state, which is crucial for space weather applications and prediction. This approach also facilitates studying the global long-term dynamics of radiation belts, enhancing our understanding of space physics and its applications to human technological systems. The project promotes the novel use of ML and DA tools for discovering missing physics in complex space physics modeling. The nonlinear wave-particle interactions (NL-WPI) were practically investigated through radiation belt modeling in comparison with observations. Integrating these techniques improves electron flux predictions, providing valuable scientific insights for space weather forecasting.
